content:
That wasn't even funny, Gal. ;P Kelvin's a scientific way of notating extreme temperatures. (Extremely cold, right?)

Living in California, I've grown up with Feet, Inches, Farenheit, Miles Per Hour, and all those other horribly un-10 measurement systems. title: Re: esdf
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
That wasn't even funny, Gal. ;P Kelvin's a scientific way of notating extreme temperatures. (Extremely cold, right?)
[hr][/quote]

Well:

C = (F - 32) * 5/9
K = C + 273.15

The reason they use Kelvin's is not for extremely low tempatures, but to make certain equations work, like:

PV = nRT (Ideal Gas Law)
Q = mK^T (^ = delta, K = Specific Heat)

They obviously would never work if you had negative tempatures.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: esdf
content:
That's two "Celcius because metric" posts, so now I have to simply say it.
Kelvin is the SI unit of temperature.
(I don't think it has any use in everyday life anywhere though; it's usually Celsius and Fahrenheit telling us the temperature.)Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: esdf
content:
Fahrenheit is best because it has more depth. Freezing is at 32 degrees, which leaves plenty of positive numbers to represent temperatures from "too cold" to "way too cold." Boiling is 180 degrees from freezing, which makes perfect sense. I'm not sure, but I think if you get another 180 degrees warmer you're freezing again.

Contrast all that with celsius. Zero is freezing. That's pretty boring, but I'll look further. 100 is boiling... what creative genius thought that up? Celsius may look nice at first, but it's got no substance. Ultimately, it is not a satisfying way to measure temperature.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/toughyorp.png[/img]

title: Re: esdf
content:
Heh, as someone who has grown up with Celcius instead, most of your arguments would apply for me too - freezing is 32 degrees? How arbitrary. 180 is boiling? Why not make it 147.4837, just to make it more exciting??? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Oh, and while it would make more sense if 360 degrees was freezing, you'd have a difficult time describing temperatures like the melting point of lead - 621.43 F? Wow, that's hot...or is it cold?

It's no wonder they came up with Kelvin, it's the only system that really makes sense (even if it is a little inconvenient for everyday use.) Having zero degrees as the lowest possible temperature seems a lot more sensible. Mind you, I'm surprised nobody has mentioned [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rankine]Rankine[/url] - the fahrenheit people's answer to Kelvin.

title: Re: esdf
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Contrast all that with celsius. Zero is freezing. That's pretty boring, but I'll look further. 100 is boiling... what creative genius thought that up? Celsius may look nice at first, but it's got no substance. Ultimately, it is not a satisfying way to measure temperature.[hr][/quote]

The problem is, interesting is often inefficient, feet and yards are interesting, but inefficient. Wheras 0-100 creates a small enough degree on a scale, and *this* is the important bit, on a scale that can be recreated in the lab.

In the old days, we didn't have commercial thermometers, you want one, you made one yourself. Fahrenheit used the boiling point of water [180] and the freezing point of a mixture of snow and sulfuric acid.[0] [As cold as anyone could get in those days] The second reference point was, at best cumbersome and inefficient. Wheras water's melting and boiling points were much more constant, allowing one to easily create a standard thermometer, especially as you could mix various amounts of boling and cold water to calibrate.

The Kelvin scale was created more for nitpicking than useability, spearheaded by the physicists who needed it for their gas laws, chemists and biologists still often use celcius, as they're familiar. This matters not as C and K are the same size, but people can identify especially with negative numbers [-20 is a BIG -ve number, must be real cold, wheras 200 is a big positive number, hot! 298K, WTF?]

So in summary: F = old fashion Down south hick temperature, C = elegant metric [Not SI] temperature K = scientific, technical nitpick temperature.

title: Re: esdf
content:
"Where are you guys getting this 180 from? The boiling point of water is 212 F."
I guess that's my fault. I meant that boiling is 180 degrees away from freezing (32 degrees), making it 212 degrees. It makes sense to me, because 180 degrees is halfway around a circle; it's like they're diametrically opposed.

Actually, a real reason to like Fahrenheit is its precision. Celsius isn't fine-grained enough for me.________________

title: Re: esdf
content:
We americans always use Fahrenheit. I don't know what good it is, though. I suppose the whole world should swich to Kelvin or something.
The metric system and all those European systems seem so much more orderly than the American ones.
Like 1,000 meters=1 kilometer or 1,000 grams=1 kilogram or
100 centimeters=1 meter
But us Americans, we have to do it the hard way. 12 inches= 1 foot How do you get that? or 5,280 ft.=1 mile.
It just seems much less efficient in a way, though now that I'm used to all the American systems I'll never be able to change.
